subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test-friendly, but not caller-friendly?
msgSnippet: ... And then there s the question of whether more error handling code is better.  The best systems I ve encountered have considered error handling an important
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>Elliotte Harold wrote:
>
>
>>Checked exceptions get
>>programmers to write a lot more error handling code than documentation
>>ever did. (Not quite as much as they should, of course, but a lot more
>>than they used to.)
>>
>>
>
>...a lot more, by percentage? I doubt it. For every person that handles
>checked exceptions, there are, I'm guessing, several (dozens?) that
>either simply wrap them in unchecked ones (fine with me) or do catch {}
>(oy). This pattern repeats, over and over.
>
>
And then there's the question of whether more error handling code is
better. The best systems I've encountered have considered error
handling an important part of the design. When it's no longer an
afterthought, you're thinking at a higher level than "I have this
exception.. what do I do with it?" When you can, you push error
handling out to the edges and try to maintain a core of code that
doesn't have to deal with errors.

Some of the worst systems I've encountered have error checks all over
the place. I blogged about null checks over here:
http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=168511

It was more controversial than I expected it to be.

Michael Feathers
